conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to use the properties of an ideal gas and the relationships described by the p-V diagram.
The p-V diagram shows the pressure (p) and volume (V) of the gas at different states. We are given the temperature at state A and need to find the temperature at state C.
From state A to state B, the volume is constant (V_A = V_B), so we use the relationship p_A/T_A = p_B/T_B.
Substituting the known values: (3 × 10^5)/300 = (1 × 10^5)/T_B, we calculate T_B = (1 × 10^5 × 300)/(3 × 10^5) = 100 K.
From state B to state C, the pressure is constant (p_B = p_C), so we use the relationship V_B/T_B = V_C/T_C.
Substituting the known values: (1 × 10^-3)/100 = (3 × 10^-3)/T_C, we calculate T_C = (3 × 10^-3 × 100)/(1 × 10^-3) = 300 K.
Convert the temperature at state C to Celsius: T_C = 300 K is equivalent to 300 - 273 = 27°C.
The temperature of the gas at state C is 27°C.
